subject: Re: JUnit article 'front page' of Builder.com
msgSnippet: Well, I just looked at the article and I had to rate it a 2 (out of 5).  No mention of a green bar. The first example has a designed to
messageBody:
Well, I just looked at the article and I had to rate it a
2 (out of 5).

<vent level="irritated">
No mention of a green bar.
The first example has a designed to fail test
(see testBooleanFalse()):

public class EmptyTest extends TestCase {
public EmptyTest(String name) {
super(name);
}

protected void setUp() { }
protected void tearDown() { }
public void testBooleanTrue() {
assertTrue(true);
}
public void testBooleanFalse() {
assertTrue(false);
}
}

I was also a bit put off by the second paragraph:

Creating the test cases, however, can be a difficult
process requiring knowledge of exactly what the code
does and how it should perform. You must carefully
create the unit tests performed by JUnit to ensure
that the tests rigorously check the code just as it
would run in the real world. In this article, we first
look at how to create unit tests and then at how to put
together test suites.

Maybe I'm being overly sensitive but it almost sounds like
"Here is a complicated thing that I'm going to explain to you"
rather than "Creating GOOD test cases is always tough. JUnit
helps by giving a framework where all you have to think about
is what you want to test..."

</vent>

Richard.
